==Japanese==

===Etymology===
{{wikipedia|lang=ja}}
{{ja-kanjitab|じ|てん|しゃ|yomi=o}}
Coined in Japan in 1870 in the [[w:Meiji period|Meiji period]] in reference to a patented [[tricycle]] design.<ref>'''1997''', Toshihiko Saitō, {{lang|ja|くるまたちの社会史: 人力車から自動車まで}} (''Kuruma-tachi no Shakai-shi: Jinrikisha Kara Jidōsha Made'', “A Social History of Cars: From Rickshaws to Automobiles”) (in Japanese), [[w:Tokyo|Tōkyō]]: [[w:Chuokoron-Shinsha|Chūōkōron-sha]], ISBN 978-4121013460</ref> Later used to refer to [[bicycle]]s.

Compound of {{cog|zhx}}-derived elements {{compound|lang=ja|sort=してんしゃ'|自|tr1=ji|t1=self|転|tr2=ten|t2=rolling|pos2=simplified modern form of {{ja-l|轉}}|車|tr3=sha|t3=vehicle}}.

===Pronunciation===
{{ja-pron|じてんしゃ|y=go|acc=2|acc2=0|acc_ref=NHK,DJR|acc2_ref=NHK,DJR}}

===Noun===
{{ja-noun|count=台|じてんしゃ|kyu=自轉車|hhira=じてんしや}}

# a [[bicycle]]

====Synonyms====
* {{qualifier|slang}} {{ja-r|チャリンコ}}
* {{qualifier|slang}} {{ja-r|チャリ}}
* {{qualifier|slang}} {{ja-r|ママチャリ}}: a bicycle with extra baskets for groceries and children, generally ridden by young mothers

====Derived terms====
{{der-top}}
* {{ja-l|自転車横断帯|じてんしゃおうだんたい|jitensha ōdantai}} {{qualifier|road sign}} [[bicycle]] [[crossing]]
* {{ja-l|自転車競技|じてんしゃきょうぎ|jitensha kyōgi}}: a [[bicycle]] [[competition]] ([[race]])
* {{ja-l|自転車競走|じてんしゃきょうそう|jitensha kyōsō}}: a [[bicycle]] [[race]]
* {{ja-l|自転車操業|じてんしゃそうぎょう|jitensha sōgyō}}: “[[bicycle]] [[operations]]” → a business model that requires regular infusions of external [[capital]] to remain [[viable]] (similar to riding a bicycle, as halting operations means immediate bankruptcy, much as stopping pedaling causes a bicycle rider to fall over)
* {{ja-l|自転車屋|じてんしゃや|jitensha-ya}}: a [[bike]] [[shop]], a [[bicycle]] [[store]]
* {{ja-l|自転車旅行|じてんしゃりょこう|jitensha ryokō}}: a [[bicycle]] [[trip]], [[bike]] [[touring]]
{{der-bottom}}

====Descendants====
* Korean: {{ko-l|자전거}}
